Presidency

Main article: Presidency of Donald Trump
For a chronological guide to this subject, see Timeline of the presidency of Donald Trump .

Transition

Main article: Presidential transition of Donald Trump
President Obama and President-elect Trump meet in the Oval Office on November 10, 2016, two days after the election.

On November 10, President-elect Trump had his first ever meeting with outgoing President Barack Obama to discuss plans for an orderly transition of power . The New York Times stated that "It was an extraordinary show of cordiality and respect between two men who have been political enemies and are stylistic opposites." [436] The BBC stated that "their antipathy was barely concealed" in "awkward photos" of the meeting. [437]

White House appointments

For a more comprehensive list, see Political appointments of Donald Trump .

New Jersey Governor Chris Christie led Trump's transition team until November 11, 2016, when Vice President-elect Mike Pence took over. [438] Since then, Trump has chosen RNC chairman Reince Priebus as White House Chief of Staff [439] and businessman and media executive Steve Bannon as White House Chief Strategist . [440]

Cabinet-level nominations

Trump's cabinet nominations included Alabama Senator Jeff Sessions as Attorney General , [441] financier Steve Mnuchin as Secretary of the Treasury , [442] retired Marine Corps General James Mattis as Secretary of Defense , [443] and ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson as Secretary of State . [444] Trump also brought on board politicians who had opposed him during the presidential campaign, notably neurosurgeon Ben Carson as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development , [445] and South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley as Ambassador to the United Nations , [446]

While most of Trump's nominees were approved by the GOP majority in the Senate, the confirmation of education reform activist Betsy DeVos as Secretary of Education [447] required Vice President Pence to cast a rare tie-breaking vote . [448]

Most cabinet members were unable to take office on Inauguration Day because of delays in the formal confirmation process . Part of the lateness was ascribed to delays in submitting background-check paperwork, part to obstructionism by Senate Democrats. [449] The last Cabinet member, Robert Lighthizer , took office as U.S. Trade Representative on May 11, 2017, more than four months after his nomination. [450]

Pre-inauguration events

On November 22, Trump outlined his plan for his first 100 days in office in a video posted on YouTube. The plan included the United States' withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership and asking the U.S. Department of Defense to develop a plan to protect the U.S. from cyber-attack . [451] [452]

On December 7, Time named Trump as its " Person of the Year ". [453] In an interview on The Today Show , he said he was honored by the award, but he took issue with the magazine for referring to him as the "President of the Divided States of America." [454] [455] He also opposed Time' s decision to change its "Man of the Year" title to "Person of the Year" in 1999, describing the action as too "politically correct". [456] On December 13 he was named Financial Times Person of the Year . [457] In December 2016, Forbes ranked Trump the second most powerful person in the world , after Vladimir Putin and before Angela Merkel . [458]

Based on intelligence reports issued from October 2016 to January 2017, the Obama administration accused the Russian government of trying to influence the U.S. presidential election in favor of Trump, by supplying the DNC emails to WikiLeaks for publication. [459] Trump, [460] WikiLeaks [461] and Russian officials [462] have denied the allegations.

First 100 days

Main article: First 100 days of Donald Trump's presidency
Chief Justice John Roberts administers the oath of office to Donald Trump as his family looks on.
Trump with Nancy Pelosi at the inauguration

Trump's inauguration as the 45th President was held on Friday, January 20, 2017. In his first week as president, Trump signed six executive orders . His first order as president set out interim procedures in anticipation of repeal of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). That same week, Trump withdrew the United States from the Trans-Pacific Partnership , re-instated the Mexico City Policy , reopened the Keystone XL and Dakota Access Pipeline construction projects and signed an executive order to begin planning, designing and constructing a new Mexico border wall and reinforce border security. [463]

On January 31, Trump nominated U.S. Appeals Court judge Neil Gorsuch to fill the vacancy left on the Supreme Court by the death of Justice Antonin Scalia . [464] The Senate confirmed the nomination on April 7, with a 54–45 vote. [465]

False and misleading statements

As president, Trump has frequently made false statements in public speeches and remarks. [466] [467] [468] Trump uttered "at least one false or misleading claim per day on 91 of his first 99 days" in office [466] and had an average of 4.9 false or misleading claims during each of his first 100 days in office. [467] "Fact Checker", a political analysis column in The Washington Post , wrote: "President Trump is the most fact-challenged politician that The Fact Checker has ever encountered... the pace and volume of the president's misstatements means that we cannot possibly keep up." [467]

Immigration orders

Main articles: Executive Order 13769 , Executive Order 13780 , and Legal challenges to Executive Orders 13769 and 13780
Trump signing Executive Order 13769 at the Pentagon as the Vice President Mike Pence and Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis look on, January 27, 2017

On January 27, Trump signed an executive order that suspended admission of refugees for 120 days and denied entry to citizens of Iraq , Iran , Libya , Somalia , Sudan , Syria , and Yemen for 90 days, citing security concerns about terrorism. The order, which went into effect immediately, caused chaos at many airports as travelers were detained on arriving in the United States or barred from boarding U.S.-bound planes. [469] The following day, thousands of protesters gathered at airports and other locations throughout the United States to protest the signing of the order and detainment of foreign nationals. [470] The administration then clarified that visitors with a green card were exempt from the ban. [471] [472] Multiple legal challenges were immediately filed, [473] and on February 5 a federal court barred enforcement of major provisions of the order. [474] [475]

On January 30, Sally Yates , the acting Attorney General , directed Justice Department lawyers not to defend the executive order and was promptly dismissed. [476] She was replaced as acting Attorney General by Dana Boente , the U.S. Attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia , who agreed to enforce the order. [477]

On March 6, 2017, Trump issued a revised executive order which, among other differences with the original order, exempted Iraqi citizens, visa-holders, and permanent residents from the temporary suspension. The order did not differentiate Syrian refugees from refugees from other countries. [478] A federal court blocked the order before it went into effect. [479] On June 26, 2017, the Supreme Court allowed a partial implementation of the executive order and scheduled a full hearing for October 2017. [2]

Dismissal of James Comey

Main article: Dismissal of James Comey

On May 9, 2017, Trump dismissed FBI Director James Comey . He attributed the action to recommendations from Attorney General Jeff Sessions and Deputy AG Rod Rosenstein , [480] which criticized Comey's conduct in the investigation about Hillary Clinton's emails . [481] On May 11, Trump stated that he was concerned with the ongoing "Russia thing" [482] and that he had intended to fire Comey earlier. [483]

According to a Comey memo of a private conversation on February 14, 2017, Trump said he "hoped" Comey would drop the investigation into Michael Flynn , [484] who had been forced to resign as National Security Advisor after it was discovered that he had misled the Vice President about communications with Russian ambassador Sergey Kislyak .

In March and April, Trump had told Comey that the ongoing suspicions formed a "cloud" impairing his presidency, [485] and asked him to publicly state that he was not personally under investigation. [486] He also asked DNI Dan Coats and NSA Director Michael Rogers to issue statements saying there was no evidence that his campaign colluded with Russia during the 2016 election. [487] Both refused, considering this an inappropriate request, although not illegal. [488] Comey eventually testified on June 8 that while he was director, the FBI investigations did not target Trump himself. [485] [489] The Washington Post later reported that within days of Comey's dismissal, the FBI started investigating whether Trump had obstructed justice. [490] Trump's lawyer Jay Sekulow stated that he had not been notified of any such investigation. [491] ABC News later reported that the special counsel is gathering preliminary information about possible obstruction of justice but has not launched a full-scale investigation. [492]

Trump attracted attention for implying that he had "tapes" of conversations with Comey, before later stating that he did not in fact have such tapes. [493]

Domestic policy

Energy

Trump's energy policy advocates domestic industrial support for both fossil and renewable energy sources in order to curb reliance on Middle-Eastern oil and possibly turn the U.S. into a net energy exporter. [494] His appointed advisers favor a less regulated energy market and, because they do not consider climate change a threat, see no need for immediate action. [495]

Climate change

Main article: Environmental policy under the Trump administration

Trump does not accept the scientific consensus on climate change . [496] [497] In 2012, he said that global warming was a hoax invented by the Chinese, but later said that he was joking. [498] [499] He has called the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) a "disgrace" and has threatened to cut its budget. [500] Trump pledged to eliminate the Clean Power Plan [501] and withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement , which calls for reductions in carbon emissions in more than 170 countries. [502] After winning the presidency, Trump said he had an "open mind" towards the Paris agreement, [503] but on June 1, 2017, he announced that the United States would withdraw from the Paris agreement , making the United States one of only three nations at the time, besides Syria and Nicaragua, not to be members. [504]

Immigration

Main article: Immigration policy of Donald Trump
Trump conferring with Vice President Mike Pence and Secretary of Homeland Security John F. Kelly , January 25, 2017

Trump's immigration policies were intensely discussed during the campaign. Trump vowed to build a more substantial wall on the Mexico–United States border to keep out illegal immigrants , a wall which Trump promised Mexico would pay for. [505] [506] [507] He pledged to massively deport illegal immigrants residing in the United States , [508] and criticized birthright citizenship as it creates " anchor babies ". [509] He said the focus of deportation would be criminals, those who have overstayed their visas, and other "security threats". [510]

Following the November 2015 Paris attacks , Trump made a controversial proposal to completely ban Muslim non-citizens from entering the United States until stronger vetting systems could be implemented. [511] [512] [513] Later in 2016 he stated that the ban would apply only to people originating from countries with a "proven history of terrorism against the United States or its allies", or countries "compromised by terrorism". [514] [515] [516]

In late January 2017, Trump issued an executive order banning the admission of immigrants from seven predominantly Muslim countries. [517] The order was imposed without warning and took effect immediately. [518] Confusion and protests caused chaos at many airports. [519] Multiple legal challenges were filed against the order, and a federal court blocked its implementation. [518] In early March 2017 Trump issued a revised order which excluded Iraq , gave specific exemptions for permanent residents , removed priorities for religious minorities (e.g. Christian refugees), and allowed for a week to implement legislation. [478] [518] Again federal courts blocked its implementation. On June 26, 2017, the U.S. Supreme Court struck down the lower courts and allowed a portion of the executive order to take effect. The Supreme Court ruled that Trump's ban on visitors from Iran, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen can be enforced if those visitors lack a "credible claim of a bona fide relationship with a person or entity in the United States." [520] The court set an October date to debate the other part of the travel ban, where an individual could claim a bona fide relationship with a person or entity in the U.S. [520] The ban is only supposed to last for 120 days, which could render the whole case moot, so the October court date might not occur. [520]

Social issues

Main article: Social policy of Donald Trump

Trump is conservative, describes himself as pro-life and generally opposes abortion; exceptions are made in cases of rape, incest , and circumstances endangering the health of the mother. [521] He has said that he is committed to appointing justices who would try to overturn the ruling in Roe v. Wade . [522] He personally supports "traditional marriage" [498] but considers the nationwide legality of same-sex marriage a "settled" issue. [522]

Trump supports a broad interpretation of the Second Amendment and says he is opposed to gun control in general, [523] [524] although his views have shifted over time. [525] Trump opposes legalizing recreational marijuana but supports legalizing medical marijuana . [526] He favors capital punishment , [527] [528] as well as the use of waterboarding . [529] [530]

Health care

In 1999, Trump told Larry King Live that "I believe in universal healthcare." [531] Trump's 2000 book, The America We Deserve , argued strongly for a single-payer healthcare system based on the Canadian model , [532] and has voiced admiration for the Scottish National Health Service . [531] [533] [534]

As a candidate Trump repeatedly vowed to repeal and replace Obamacare . [535] [536] Starting early in his presidency he urged Congress to repeal and replace it. In May the United States House of Representatives voted to repeal the ACA. [537] However, the Senate tried for several months but was unable to pass any of several versions of a repeal bill. [538] Trump has expressed a desire to "let Obamacare fail", and the Trump administration has cut the ACA enrollment period in half and drastically reduced funding for advertising and other ways to encourage enrollment. [539] [540] [541]

Trump aims to streamline the Department of Veterans Affairs , getting rid of backlogs and waitlists , and upgrading relevant facilities. [542] On his first Monday in office, Trump issued a federal hiring freeze on the VA. [543]

Education

Trump has stated his support for school choice and local control for primary and secondary schools. [544] He opposes the Common Core State Standards Initiative for primary and secondary schools, [545] and has called Common Core "a disaster" that must be ended. [546] He has stated he would abolish all or part of the Department of Education . [547]

Economy and trade

Main article: Economic policy of Donald Trump
Trump speaking to auto workers in Michigan in March 2017

Trump's campaign tax plan called for levelling the corporate tax rate to 15%, eliminating various business loopholes and deductions, [371] and reducing the number of brackets for personal income tax: the top rate would be reduced from 39.6% to 25%, a large "zero bracket" would be created, and the alternative minimum tax and estate tax (which currently applies to individual estates over $5.45 million or $10.9 million per married couple) would both be eliminated. [548] His comments about the minimum wage have been inconsistent. [549] [550] [551]

Trump identifies as a " free trader ", but says that trade must be "reasonably fair". [552] He has often been called a " protectionist ", [553] [554] [555] because of his criticism of NAFTA , [556] [557] the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), [558] and his proposal to raise tariffs on Chinese and Mexican exports to the United States significantly. [559] [560] He has also been critical of the World Trade Organization , threatening to leave unless his proposed tariffs are accepted. [561] [562] However, Trump has been very keen to support a "fair" post- Brexit trade deal with the United Kingdom, [563] which Trump says would be "good for both sides". [564]

Government size and deregulation

Trump's early policies have favored deregulation and a smaller federal government. He became the first president in sixteen years to sign a Congressional Review Act disapproval resolution; the law had been used only once before. [565] During his first six weeks in office, he abolished ninety federal regulations. [566] [567]

On January 23, 2017, Trump ordered a temporary government-wide hiring freeze , which allows for exceptions, primarily for jobs deemed vital for national security or public safety reasons. [568] [569] The Comptroller General of the Government Accountability Office told a House committee that hiring freezes have not proven to be effective in reducing costs. [570] Unlike some past freezes, the current freeze bars agencies from adding contractors to make up for employees leaving. [570]

A week later Trump signed Executive Order 13771 , directing administrative agencies to repeal two existing regulations for every new regulation they issue. [571] [572] Harvard Law professor Jody Freeman said that the order would do no more than slow the regulatory process, because it did not block rules required by statute. [573]

On February 24, 2017, Trump ordered the agencies to create task forces to determine which regulations are deemed burdensome to the U.S. economy. [574] Agency defenders expressed opposition to Trump's criticisms, saying that the bureaucracy exists to protect people against well-organized, well-funded interest groups. [575]

Foreign policy

Main articles: Foreign policy of the Donald Trump administration and Foreign policy of Donald Trump
President Trump together with other leaders at the 43rd G7 summit in Italy, May 2017

Trump has been described as non-interventionist [576] [577] and nationalist. [578] He repeatedly stated that he supports " America First " foreign policy. [579] He supports increasing United States military defense spending, [578] but favors decreasing United States spending on NATO and in the Pacific region. [580] He says America should look inward, stop "nation building", and re-orient its resources toward domestic needs. [577] As a candidate he questioned whether he, as president, would automatically extend security guarantees to NATO members , [581] and suggested that he might leave NATO unless changes are made to the alliance. [582] But as president he has reaffirmed the U.S. commitment to NATO. [583]

In order to confront the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS), Trump in 2015 called for seizing the oil in ISIS-occupied areas, using U.S. air power and ground troops. [584] In 2016, Trump advocated sending 20,000 to 30,000 U.S. troops to the region, [585] [586] a position he later retracted. [587] Regarding the Israeli–Palestinian conflict , Trump has stated the importance of being a neutral party during potential negotiations, while also having stated that he is "a big fan of Israel". [588] During the campaign he said he would relocate the U.S. embassy in Israel to Jerusalem from its current location, Tel Aviv , although he has not pursued that proposal as president. [589] On May 22, 2017, Trump was the first U.S. president to visit the Western Wall in Jerusalem, during his first foreign trip, visiting Israel, Italy, the Vatican , and Belgium . [590]

Both as a candidate and as president, Trump repeatedly said he wants a good relationship with Russia. [591] [592] Trump has pledged to hold a summit meeting with Vladimir Putin . [593] He added that Russia could help the U.S. in fighting ISIS militants . [594] On April 7, 2017, Trump ordered a missile strike against a Syrian airfield in retaliation for the Khan Shaykhun chemical attack . [595]

North Korea became a major issue in mid-2017. During the campaign and the early months of his presidency, Trump had hoped that China would help to rein in North Korea's nuclear ambitions and missile tests. [596] However, North Korea accelerated its missile testing, leading to an increase in tensions in April 2017. [596] In July, the country tested two long-range missiles identified by Western observers as intercontinental ballistic missiles , potentially capable of reaching Alaska, Hawaii, and the U.S. mainland. [597] [598] In August, Trump dramatically escalated his rhetoric against North Korea, warning that further provocation against the U.S. will be met with "fire and fury like the world has never seen." [599] North Korean leader Kim Jong-un then threatened to direct the country's next missile test toward Guam . Trump responded that if North Korea took steps to attack Guam, "[t]hings [would] happen to them like they never thought possible." [600]

Impeachment efforts

Main article: Efforts to impeach Donald Trump

On July 12, 2017, California Representative Brad Sherman formally introduced an article of impeachment, H. Res. 438, [601] accusing the president of obstructing justice regarding the investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election. [602]

2020 presidential campaign

Main article: Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2020

Trump signaled his intention to run for a second term by filing with the FEC within hours of assuming the presidency. [603] [604] This transformed his 2016 election committee into a 2020 reelection one. [605] Trump marked the official start of the campaign with a campaign rally in Melbourne, Florida , on February 18, 2017, less than a month after taking office. [606] By February 1, 2017, the campaign had already raised over $7 million. [607]
